author: Standardqueso
title: Great addition for the Fire Station 6382
review: My mom bought me this like a month after I received the Fire station 6382. Was perfect because the white helmet, the walkie talkie, give this guy the perfect look for a chief fireman. Due to the good size of the station I could park the car outside and with an emergency the fire squad was complete.

author: CamberbrickGreen
title: Fire Chief Embarrassed By Brigade Go-Kart
review:
For little hands this is a satisfying and fun build. It also qualified as an economy or pocket money set that has movement and rolls the Fire Chief (usually with a white hat) around as fast as he is pushed...and he'd want to move fast too and not just in emergencies... 

Flame stricken buildings can probably go burn because when the firemen arrive by engine and truck they can do little but fall down laughing when Chiefy turns up in something that looks like what grandpa MFs use to mow the lawn.

Minifigures:

[··][··][··]

Typical fire chief in familiar uniform.

Kiddy Car
Go-karts and lawn mower size transport have long been acceptable minifigure transportation but it seems out of place when more suitable and scale vehicles inconsistently exist. Alternate models could be seen as preferable in some 'go-kart' sets.

I digress, this is a fun little set for fun little people and many kids probably ended up with multiples. At this time the mini figure radios were still sought after as a cool brick/piece. Also the fire symbol brick always made a good stove or fire place in peoples houses or could be placed on a siblings model: "Your model is now on fire".

The old fire service stuff can be found preferable to the over the top modern equivalents, apart from the Town Exclusives amazing 1930s Fire Station- worth 100 of the modern fire service sets. Just remember if this Chief drives in any either of these, he may look out of place.

author: tinbrick
title: Good things come in small packages
review: I remember getting this set for the first time in the three-pack which included the tow-truck and doctor's car. The fact it is small, easy to build, lacking in any bells and whistles and pretty much a set picked up as a last minute gift meant I ended up with lots of these little fellas. Yes, as mentioned a previous review, any fire chief turning up to an incident in a go kart would be a laughing stock. And yes, in an actual fire emergency the vehicle is next to useless (you can't even rescue a cat stuck up a tree). But it was always fun to play with and sums up the innocence of Lego when you're a kid before Lego video games and Star Wars kits that are going for $1000 online! I still remember how to make the cart off by heart more than 28 years later and this alone would always endear the set to me. 5 out of 5.

author: Niki124
title: Fun and striking little vehicle
review: This looks like a simple little car to build but the layers involved to ensure the sirens are incorporated means there's more to it than first meets the eye. It also means there's enough pieces to get a bit creative with one's own designs. This was the first set we owned which incorporated the one-piece moulded chair, which quickly became a favourite piece. At the time, the minifigure stood out from other firefighters thanks to the white helmet, which designated the character as the Fire Chief, but this was undermined somewhat when later sets gave all firefighters white helmets instead of the conventional black.
